qa_pairs.question: When did Kinross acquire the Dvoinoye property, and what were the key details regarding the mine's construction, production start, and cost as outlined in the source context?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Kinross acquired the Dvoinoye property in 2010.<cite>[S3][S6]</cite></statement> <statement>The underground mine was constructed at a cost of US$360-million.<cite>[S3][S8]</cite></statement> <statement>Production at the mine began in October 2013.<cite>[S8]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Dvoinoye Gold Mine


# Dvoinoye Gold Mine



The **Dvoinoye Gold Mine** is an underground gold mine in the Bilibinsky District of the Chukotka Autonomous Okrug of Russia. [S2] The mine is owned by Canadian mining company Kinross Gold and is approximately 100 kilometres (60 mi) from their Kupol Gold Mine. [S3] Originally the site of a surface mine, Kinross acquired the property in 2010, and built the underground mine at a cost of US$360-million. [S4] The mine began production in 2013. [S5] ## History

In 2010 Kinross acquired the rights to the Dvoinoye property, which is located approximately 100 kilometres (60 mi) from another Kinross mine, Kupol. [S6] The property was purchased from Northern Gold; an open pit mine previously operated on the site, producing 250 tonnes per day, six months per year. [S7] After acquisition, Kinross completed diamond drilling on the property, and a feasibility study. [S8] Production began at the mine in October 2013, and the mine was built "on time and on budget" at a cost of US$360-million. [S9] ## Operation

The Dvoinoye mine is expected to operate at the rate of 1000 tonnes of ore per day, which will be processed at Kupol, producing a gold and silver doré. [S10] The mine is expected to produce up to 300,000 troy ounces (9,300,000 g) of gold-equivalent per year during the first three years of production. [S11] To handle the additional ore from Dvoinoye, capacity at the mineral processing facility at Kupol was increased by an additional 1000 tonnes per day, yielding a total capacity of 4,500 tonnes per day. [S12] ## Reserves and resources

The Dvoinoye Gold Mine has a NI 43-101 proven and probable reserves of more than two million tonnes of gold ore, at a grade of approximately 19 grams per tonne gold and 28.5 grams per tonne silver. [S13] There is an additional 280,000 tonnes in the measured, indicated, and inferred categories, although at a lower grade.

qa_pairs.question: How did the operational capacity of the Kupol processing facility change to accommodate the Dvoinoye mine's ore, and what was the total capacity after the expansion?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The operational capacity of the Kupol processing facility was increased by 1000 tonnes per day to accommodate the Dvoinoye mine's ore. This expansion resulted in a total capacity of 4,500 tonnes per day at the Kupol processing facility.<cite>[S12]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What is the projected annual gold-equivalent production from the Dvoinoye mine during its initial years, and how does this align with its ore processing capacity?

[S1] Dvoinoye Gold Mine


# Dvoinoye Gold Mine



The **Dvoinoye Gold Mine** is an underground gold mine in the Bilibinsky District of the Chukotka Autonomous Okrug of Russia. [S2] The mine is owned by Canadian mining company Kinross Gold and is approximately 100 kilometres (60 mi) from their Kupol Gold Mine. [S3] Originally the site of a surface mine, Kinross acquired the property in 2010, and built the underground mine at a cost of US$360-million. [S4] The mine began production in 2013. [S5] ## History

In 2010 Kinross acquired the rights to the Dvoinoye property, which is located approximately 100 kilometres (60 mi) from another Kinross mine, Kupol. [S6] The property was purchased from Northern Gold; an open pit mine previously operated on the site, producing 250 tonnes per day, six months per year. [S7] After acquisition, Kinross completed diamond drilling on the property, and a feasibility study. [S8] Production began at the mine in October 2013, and the mine was built "on time and on budget" at a cost of US$360-million. [S9] ## Operation

The Dvoinoye mine is expected to operate at the rate of 1000 tonnes of ore per day, which will be processed at Kupol, producing a gold and silver doré. [S10] The mine is expected to produce up to 300,000 troy ounces (9,300,000 g) of gold-equivalent per year during the first three years of production. [S11] To handle the additional ore from Dvoinoye, capacity at the mineral processing facility at Kupol was increased by an additional 1000 tonnes per day, yielding a total capacity of 4,500 tonnes per day. [S12] ## Reserves and resources

The Dvoinoye Gold Mine has a NI 43-101 proven and probable reserves of more than two million tonnes of gold ore, at a grade of approximately 19 grams per tonne gold and 28.5 grams per tonne silver. [S13] There is an additional 280,000 tonnes in the measured, indicated, and inferred categories, although at a lower grade.
